INVESTIGATION:
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4138 Bedding and linen.
Section (1) Each resident shall be provided with an individual bed with
Description a clean pillow, mattress and sufficient clean blankets.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth doesn’t have a blanket to sleep with.
Investigation Therapist was interviewed on 01/18/2023 during an announced face-
to-face visit at the facility. She confirmed that Youth A had a safety
blanket that she was trying to rip and bite during the incident in
question. Therapist stated that it has been her experience with this
specific youth that any scraps of fabric like a ripped blanket can be
used as means for self-harm when she is escalated. She stated that
staff had been trying to convince her and de-escalate her to lay down
and communicated the whole time that she would be able to have her
blanket back when she came back to baseline. Therapist confirmed that
the incident in question lasted an hour or so and that it ended with
Youth A being able to have her blanket back to go to sleep. She stated
that it was her recollection that there were not any issues regarding
Youth A the rest of that night.
Youth A/Complainant was interviewed on 01/18/2023 during an
unannounced face-to-face visit to the facility. She stated that the
2

incident in question occurred about a week ago. There were several
staff involved, including Therapist. Youth A stated that she had run
away from the facility earlier in the night and was picked up by law
enforcement and brought back. She stated that she thought they were
"strangers" at first. She admitted to being escalated while in the unit
after coming back and trying to tear up her safety blanket. She stated
that staff asked her if she was going to attempt to self-harm herself with
the blanket, and then stated that she has attempted this in the past.
Youth A denied that she was attempting to harm herself. Youth A
stated that staff took away her blanket temporarily at the instruction of
Therapist. Youth A stated that at that point she was banging and
punching the wall behind her bed and asked if she could call DHHS
Centralized intake to report that she was not being given back her
blanket. She stated that she knew it was 72° inside the unit at the time
because there had been a conversation about the thermostat earlier in
the evening. At that point she was wearing shorts and a T-shirt. Youth
A stated that her sweatpants and sweatshirt were also temporarily
taken away in that moment. Youth A stated that she still did not have
her blanket after a period of time and wanted to go to bed. Youth A
recalled requesting that she be able to call law enforcement, which the
facility allowed. After this phone call, Youth A stated that she began to
calm down, and that staff gave her a blanket back so that she could go
to sleep. Youth A reiterated that she believed that she should not have
had the blanket taken away in the first place, and that she was not self-
harming with the blanket at that moment.
Analysis Through face-to-face interviews of staff and youth at the facility it was
found that there was not sufficient evidence to show that there was a
rule violation. Youth A was brought back to the facility by Law
Enforcement and Youth A's blanket was taken away temporarily as a
safety measure but was provided back to her upon her de-escalation.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
